channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Volkswagen Outlines Plans to Beat Tesla by 2025
item.description: Big picture: Analysts see room for Tesla and Volkswagen in the growing EV market, per Bloomberg.  And with 70 new electric models on the way this decade, Volkswagen could match Tesla EV sales as soon as 2022 and outstrip it by a margin of 300,000 come 2025, UBS predicts.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: If You Work in Finance, You Might Be Back in the Office Soon
item.description: Less than half of Manhattan's 1 million office employees are expected to return to the office by September, per the Partnership for New York City.  Then yesterday, we learned that JPMorgan is planning for summer interns in New York and London to work in-person, according to the NYT.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Architects Win Pritzker Prize for Work on Public Housing
item.description: Bottom line: "If we observe carefully, if we look at things with fresh eyes, there is always something positive to take from an existing situation," Lacaton said. We'd challenge them to bring that energy to the FBI headquarters in DC.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Believe It or Not, Bitcoin Could Be Better Than Gold
item.description: Bitcoin is... A Bit of Bitcoin BasicsYou could think of Bitcoin as magic internet money—and yes, we at Morning Brew are known for our technical economics vocabulary.  Think GoldThe best case scenario for Bitcoin probably looks something like the consistent historical value of gold. What’s super cool is that, even if the hype fades, Bitcoin may actually more likely become ensconced in our society as a thing that stores value. Its Place in Your PortfolioBitcoin has a way to go when it comes to being taken seriously by institutions and governments.  The Invisible Potential of BitcoinYou can’t see Bitcoin. File under: The best tax help around. *Bitcoin has the potential to become the digital version of gold. While gold was once traded as a physical currency, its value in the stock market is no longer tied to its industrial value. Plenty of smart people think it’s a good move to invest in Bitcoin.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: The UK Updates Their Inflation Basket To Reflect New Consumer Habits
item.description: Bottom line: In total, 17 items were added to the basket while 10 items, including gold chains, canteen sandwiches, and Axminster carpets, were dropped.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 16
item.description: ) its CEO and CFO to esteemed new positions, though to the relief of many Tesla investors, they'll also keep their previous titles.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: ViacomCBS and Discovery Are Quietly Having Incredible Years
item.description: Since launching in December, Discovery+ has attracted more than 11 million subscribers, while Paramount+, ViacomCBS's streaming service, is believed to have around 8–9 million subscribers.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Germany, Italy Join Neighbors in Suspending AstraZeneca Vaccine
item.description: Yesterday, Germany, France, and Italy joined several of their neighbors in suspending AstraZeneca's two-shot Covid vaccine following reports of blood clots. Over half of Italy's population is back under strict lockdowns. Indonesia and the Democratic Republic of the Congo also suspended rollout.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Biden Expected to Propose First Major Tax Hike Since 1993
item.description: And the Tax Foundation estimates that some of the proposed changes to corporate taxes would reduce US GDP by 0.8% and wages by 0.7% in the long run.    When Trump slashed the corporate rate to 21% in 2017, he wasn't the first to bat for business interests. Bumping the income tax to 39.6% for those earning $400,000+  Taxing capital gains like normal income if you earn $1+ millionIncreasing estate taxes to 45% for assets worth $1+ millionSo, if you still clip coupons, don't expect any changes. These increases largely follow Biden's campaign proposals to only tax high-earners.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: ViacomCBS and Discovery Are Quietly Having Incredible Years
item.description: But while the biggest players have gobbled up hundreds of millions of subscribers... Since the start of 2021, ViacomCBS stock is up +156% and Discovery has gained +141%, powered by the launches of their respective streaming services, Paramount+ and Discovery+.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: The Week Ahead
item.description: Everything else:St. Patrick's Day is on Wednesday. As you can see above, Chicago is ready to celebrate. Here's the bracket. The entire tournament is taking place in Indiana this year. For best picture, Nomadland, The Trial of the Chicago 7, Promising Young Woman, Minari, and Mank appear to be locks.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 15
item.description: (Kiplinger) Here's a mathematical answer. Read: How much bitcoin should you own?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Grammys Pay Tribute to Local Music Venues
item.description: The ceremony also paid tribute to independent music venues hurt by the pandemic, featuring bartenders, box-office managers, and other industry workers from iconic venues like Nashville's Station Inn and NYC's Apollo Theater.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Stimulus Checks Begin Arriving
item.description: + If you're eligible, use the IRS's Get My Payment tool to see when your check is coming. The IRS told H&R Block that most eligible Americans will receive theirs on Wednesday.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: NFTs, Bitcoin, SPACs, Snakers: Too Many Crazes to Count
item.description: A short listCrypto: Last March, bitcoin was hovering just above $5,000; on Saturday, it hit an all-time high above $61,000. The amount wagered on SPACs to fall in value has tripled since the start of the year, per the WSJ. Zoom out: No one knows exactly if/when any of these "mini-bubbles'' will pop but, at least in the SPAC world, some think it might be soon. Even NFTs were being developed as early as 2017. SPACs have been around for decades, sneaker-flipping dates back to 1985, and trading cards, well…you get the point. Plus, it’s not like any of the "crazes" described above are that new.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NFTs, Bitcoin, SPACs, Snakers: Too Many Crazes to Count
item.description: A short listCrypto: Last March, bitcoin was hovering just above $5,000; on Saturday, it hit an all-time high of above $61,000. The amount wagered on SPACs to fall in value has tripled since the start of the year, per the WSJ. Zoom out: No one knows exactly if/when any of these "mini-bubbles'' will pop but, at least in the SPAC world, some think it might be soon. Even NFTs were being developed as early as 2017. SPACs have been around for decades, sneaker-flipping dates back to 1985, and trading cards, well…you get the point. Plus, it’s not like any of the "crazes" described above are that new.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Roblox Teaches Gen Alpha About the Economy
item.description: Armor, weapons, facial expressions, wings, Sir Rich McMoneyston, III disguises, and other items that augment players’ avatarsPerks that help players in games, like a bigger duffel bag for robbing banks in the Grand Theft Auto-reminiscent Jailbreak gameAccess to games like Welcome to Bloxburg, which charges 25 Robux for entryAdvertisements for the games they create themselvesUnlike its players, Roblox’s economy has a wrinkleDevelopers who create on the Roblox platform can also get paid in Robux, which they can later exchange for USD.  So what do players spend all that virtual currency on? For $4.99, players can buy 400 Robux, and they get a Costco-level discount for buying “value packs” that can run as high as $100 or subscribing for recurring Robux installments. Virtual economies have only become more popular and varied in the years since.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Toronto Restaurant Renames Menu Items to Fool Expense Reports
item.description: Here’s what the menu looks like from Uber Eats:  Just don’t be the person who orders their ergonomic aluminum laptop stand well-done.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: Stats Takeover
item.description: The rate of twin births has grown by a third since the 1980s, which the researchers attribute to a rise in fertility treatments. Babies stat: More twins are being born now than at any point in history, according to a study published yesterday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Chewy Cofounder to Lead GameStop’s E-commerce Business
item.description: His next task will be to turn GameStop’s reputation from “ye olde gaming equipment pawn shop” into “Amazon for gaming.”
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Why Marco Rubio Supported Amazon’s Unionization Drive
item.description: the Amazon workers’ votes on whether to unionize are due by the 29th. In a USA Today op-ed published yesterday, Rubio railed against the company and backed the workers currently pushing to unionize at a warehouse in Bessemer, Alabama. Rubio maintained in the op-ed that “adversarial relations between labor and management are wrong.”
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: US Hits 100 Million Vaccine Doses Administered
item.description: US: The country hit a milestone of 100 million vaccine doses administered yesterday, and 13.5% of all US adults are fully vaccinated (meaning two doses of Moderna or Pfizer-BioNTech, or one of J&J). How we got here: The US ordered 300 million doses of AstraZeneca’s vaccine last year, but regulators are still waiting on data from a clinical trial to begin the authorization process. The debate over unused dosesA cross-border kerfuffle is brewing over millions of unused doses of AstraZeneca’s vaccine.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Why Marco Rubio Supported Amazon’s Unionization Drive
item.description: He clarified that he supported the Bessemer workers because Amazon’s leadership “has decided to wage culture war against working-class values.” In a USA Today op-ed published yesterday, Rubio railed against the company and backed the workers currently pushing to unionize at a warehouse in Bessemer, Alabama.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: How a Former NBA Player Turned Entrepreneur Does His Taxes
item.description: MB: OK so one more question about basketball.  One thing I learned along the way is that I don’t like to write alone.  PB: Yes, it’s called Ball Boy and it’s about a kid named Gray whose mother moves him from LA to Beaudelaire, Kansas.  PS: Luckily, no, but there was one time when someone broke in and stole all of our wallets.  MB: Don’t pro athletes have to deal with a lot of state taxes too? So I had to stash the money in my shoes and hope that no one would take it while we were playing.  MB: How did you pay yourself at Writers Blok, and now with The Process? It’s something that mostly affects actors and athletes, but they aren’t going to complain and no one really feels bad for them. And he was like that with everyone.  PS: So, we established it as a 501(c)3 nonprofit, which ended up being a bad idea because it’s hard to get loans if you’re a nonprofit. How did you go about organizing your finances back then?  MB: Tell us a little bit about that.  PS: One time I tried to do them myself on TurboTax. I messed it up so badly that my accountant had to write a letter to the IRS and say, if you help us fix this, Paul promises to never, ever do his taxes on his own again. From 2001–2002 I played with the Panionios Athens in Greece, and one nice thing was they covered the taxes in their country.  PS: When I was in the NBA, I always thought I’d write a book afterward.  MB: You also have a new book out now, right? Now we have a long history of working together and he understands my background as well as where I want to go in the future.  MB: So how do you work through that? Do you remember how you did your taxes back then?  PS: At Writers Blok I paid myself as a contractor, so I had a 1099. So we started organizing it a bit better, providing wine and cream pies, and then it grew into Writers Blok, which I like to describe as a yoga studio but for writing. I found someone after about a year of playing basketball professionally, and he’s still the person I work with today. What was it like to play with the greats?
item.author: Devin Tomb

item.title: Brew Crossword: HBO
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: March 12
item.description: (ProPublica) Read: The lost year: What the pandemic cost teenagers.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Global Food Prices Rise for Ninth Straight Month
item.description: In February, global food prices rose 2.4% for their ninth straight month of increases.  Zoom out: The pandemic pushed an additional 13+ million Americans into food insecurity, but the situation is even worse in the world's poorest countries.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: South Korean e-Commerce Giant Makes US Trading Debut
item.description: Yesterday, the South Korean e-commerce giant Coupang became the largest foreign company to make its US trading debut since Alibaba went public in 2014.
item.author: Toby Howell
